title: Sorin Avram
text:
Sorin Aristotel Avram (29 March 1943 – 29 September 2015) was a <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and coach.
He started his career in 1956, by joining the youth team of Letea Bacău. From there he moved to <a href="FCM%20Bac%C4%83u">Dinamo Bacău</a> in 1959 and then to Viitorul Bucharest in 1962.
Viitorul Bucharest was a project of the Romanian Football Federation in which they gather the best young players and formed a team which played in the Romanian top division, <a href="Divizia%20A">Divizia A</a>.
From Viitorul, Avram joined <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a> in 1963. Six years later he joined <a href="FC%20Farul%20Constan%C5%A3a">FC Farul Constanţa</a> and then moved back to <a href="FCM%20Bac%C4%83u">FCM Bacău</a> in 1970, ended his career in 1973 at only 30.
He played a total of 226 games in <a href="Divizia%20A">Divizia A</a>, scoring 38 goals. He was Romanian football champion with <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a> in 1968 and won the <a href="Romanian%20Cup">Romanian Cup</a>, again with <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a>, in 1966 and 1967. He also won 12 caps for <a href="Romania%20national%20football%20team">Romania</a>, scoring one goal. He played for Romania at the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a>.
As a coach, he was head-coach of <a href="FCM%20Bac%C4%83u">FCM Bacău</a> for nine games during the 1991–92 season.
